title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.


#Load Libraries

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.1     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(vroom)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'vroom'
#> 
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:readr':
#> 
#>     as.col_spec, col_character, col_date, col_datetime, col_double,
#>     col_factor, col_guess, col_integer, col_logical, col_number,
#>     col_skip, col_time, cols, cols_condense, cols_only, date_names,
#>     date_names_lang, date_names_langs, default_locale, fwf_cols,
#>     fwf_empty, fwf_positions, fwf_widths, locale, output_column,
#>     problems, spec

library(data.table)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'data.table'
#> 
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:lubridate':
#> 
#>     hour, isoweek, mday, minute, month, quarter, second, wday, week,
#>     yday, year
#> 
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr':
#> 
#>     between, first, last
#> 
#> The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':
#> 
#>     transpose

library(tictoc)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'tictoc'
#> 
#> The following object is masked from 'package:data.table':
#> 
#>     shift

library(dplyr)
library(readxl)


1 Define column types for vroom

col_types <- list(
  id = col_character(),
  type = col_character(),
  number = col_character(),
  country = col_character(),
  date = col_date("%Y-%m-%d"),
  abstract = col_character(),
  title = col_character(),
  kind = col_character(),
  num_claims = col_double(),
  filename = col_character(),
  withdrawn = col_double()
)



2 The reduced data set for the year 2014


3 Read the data into a tibble

patent_tbl <- vroom(
  file = "C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/Wrangling/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/patent.tsv", 
  delim = "\t"
  #col_types = col_types,
  #na = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

#> Rows: 327014 Columns: 3
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: "\t"
#> chr  (1): id
#> dbl  (1): num_claims
#> date (1): date
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

assignee_tbl <- vroom(
  file = "C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/Wrangling/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/assignee.tsv", 
  delim = "\t", 
  col_types = col_types,
  na = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: number,
#> country, date, abstract, title, kind, num_claims, filename, withdrawn

patent_assignee_tbl <- vroom(
  file = "C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/Wrangling/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/patent_assignee.tsv", 
  delim = "\t", 
  col_types = col_types,
  na = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: id, type,
#> number, country, date, abstract, title, kind, num_claims, filename, withdrawn

uspc_tbl <- vroom(
  file = "C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/Wrangling/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/uspc.tsv", 
  delim = "\t", 
  col_types = col_types,
  na = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

#> Warning: The following named parsers don't match the column names: id, type,
#> number, country, date, abstract, title, kind, num_claims, filename, withdrawn


#Joining the tables

patent_joined_table <- patent_assignee_tbl %>%
  inner_join(assignee_tbl, by = c("assignee_id" = "id")) %>%
  inner_join(patent_tbl, by = c("patent_id" = "id"))

#What US company/corporation has the most patents? List the 10 US companies with the most assigned/granted patents.

us_patent_counts <- patent_joined_table %>%
  group_by(organization) %>%
  summarise(total_patents = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(total_patents))

top_10_us_companies <- head(us_patent_counts, 10)

top_10_us_companies



  



#What US organization had the most patents granted in August 2014? List the top 10 companies with the most new granted patents for August 2014.

us_patent_counts_aug_2014 <- patent_joined_table %>%
  filter(format(date, "%Y-%m") == "2014-08") %>%
  group_by(organization) %>%
  summarise(total_patents = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(total_patents)) %>%
  select(organization, total_patents)

top_10_us_companies_aug_2014 <- head(us_patent_counts_aug_2014, 10)

top_10_us_companies_aug_2014

title: Data Visualization
text:
#Loading Libraries
#Map the time course of the cumulative Covid-19 cases!
#Filter the data

title: Tidyverse
text:
Add a language to syntax highlight code blocks: #Loading Libraries

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.1     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(tibble)
library(readr)
library(dplyr)
library(magrittr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'magrittr'
#> 
#> The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':
#> 
#>     set_names
#> 
#> The following object is masked from 'package:tidyr':
#> 
#>     extract

library(tidyr)
library(stringr)
library(ggplot2)
library(readxl)
library(lubridate)

#Read Data

bikes_tbl <- read_excel(path ="C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/ds_data_assets/bikes.xlsx")
orderlines_tbl <- read_excel(path = "C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/ds_data_assets/orderlines.xlsx")

#> New names:
#> • `` -> `...1`

bikeshops_tbl  <- read_excel("C:/Users/Jeevan/OneDrive/Documents/TUHH/Business/ss23-bdsb-Jeevankumarhl/assets/ds_data_assets/bikeshops.xlsx")

#Joining the tables

left_join(orderlines_tbl, bikes_tbl, by = c("product.id" = "bike.id"))



  


bike_orderlines_joined_tbl   <-   orderlines_tbl   %>%
  left_join(bikes_tbl, by = c("product.id" = "bike.id"))  %>%
  left_join(bikeshops_tbl, by = c("customer.id" = "bikeshop.id"))

#glimpse(bike_orderlines_joined_tbl)

#Finding City name from location

bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_joined_tbl %>% 
 separate(col = location,
           into = c("city","state"),
           sep = ", ",
           convert = T) %>%
  separate(col    = category,
           into   = c("category.1", "category.2", "category.3"),
           sep    = " - ") %>%
  
  
  mutate(total_price = price * quantity)

#State with Highest Revenue and Graph

sales_by_location_tbl  <-  bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  select(state, total_price) %>%
  group_by(state) %>%
  summarize(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".",
                                     decimal.mark = ",",
                                     prefix = "",
                                     suffix = "€"))


glimpse(sales_by_location_tbl)

#> Rows: 12
#> Columns: 3
#> $ state      <chr> "Baden-Württemberg", "Bavaria", "Berlin", "Bremen", "Hambur…
#> $ sales      <dbl> 6521090, 6742819, 1128433, 10653499, 3874756, 1558901, 4107…
#> $ sales_text <chr> "6.521.090€", "6.742.819€", "1.128.433€", "10.653.499€", "3…

# ADD THIS IN THE WEBSITE WHILE ADDING THE SCRIPT{r plot, fig.width=10, fig.height=7}

sales_by_location_tbl %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = state, y = sales)) +
  
  geom_col(fill = "#2DC6D6") +
  geom_label(aes(label = sales_text)) +
  #geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)+
  scale_y_continuous( labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".",
                                                     decimal.mark = ",",
                                                     prefix = "",
                                                     suffix = " €")) +
  
  labs(
    title = "Revenue by Location(State)",
    subtitle = "Trend",   #North Rhine-Westphalia has the highest revenue.
    x = "",
    y = "Revenue"
  ) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))









1 Analyze the sales by location and year (facet_wrap)

sales_by_location_cat_1_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  select(state, total_price, category.1) %>%
  group_by(state, category.1) %>%
  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))

#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'state'. You can override using the
#> `.groups` argument.

#sales_by_location_cat_1_tbl
sales_by_location_cat_1_tbl %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = category.1, y = sales, fill = state)) +
  geom_col() +
  facet_wrap(~ state) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title = "Revenue by category and state",
    subtitle = "Trend in sales of products in each state",
    fill = "State List"
  )+ theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Data Acquisition
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Class Notes
text:
IMPORTANT: You can delete everything in here and start fresh. You might want to start by not deleting anything above this line until you know what that stuff is doing.
This is an .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.

title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website everytime before you want to upload changes
